name: A-2 system
description: Early example of free software distributed with source code

name: SHARE Operating System
description: Shared operating system distributed by the SHARE user group

name: Unix
description: Distributed freely at first to academic institutions

name: SPICE
description: Simulation software for electronic circuits. Continues to be developed

name: TeX
description: Typesetting system by Donald Knuth, still widely used.

name: GNU Emacs
description: Popular text editor from the GNU project

name: X Window System
description: Graphical windowing system for bitmap displays

name: Mozilla Firefox
description: Open-source web browser from Mozilla and derived from Netscape

name: Ubuntu
description: Popular Linux distribution based on Debian

name: Android
description: Mobile operating system based on Linux and developed by Google

name: Visual Studio Code
description: Free source-code editor with support for debugging, syntax highlighting, etc.

name: SCO v. IBM & Oracle v. Google
period.label: Mainstream Adoption

name: Free sharing of technological information
period.label: Early Open Sharing
description: This concept refers to the open exchange of knowledge, designs, and software to encourage innovation and collaboration.

name: Public domain software
period.label: Early Open Sharing
description: Public domain software is software that has no copyright restrictions, allowing anyone to use, modify, and distribute it freely. In the 1980s, alongside the free software movement, software with source code was shared on BBS networks.

name: IBM mainframe
period.label: Commercialization
description: IBM mainframes are powerful, high-performance computers designed for large-scale processing, critical applications, and enterprise computing.

name: IBM 701
period.label: Commercialization
description: IBM's first commercial scientific computer, introduced in 1952.

name: Proprietary software
period.label: Commercialization
description: Software sold under restrictive licenses limits usage, modification, and distribution.

name: Proprietary OS with user-contributed software
period.label: Commercialization
description: Proprietary operating systems are privately owned and controlled software platforms, restricting modification and distribution.

name: Copyrights and patents
period.label: Commercialization
description: They protect intellectual property. Before 1974, software was not copyrightable until US Commission on New Technological Uses of Copyrighted Works (CONTU) recognized computer programs as eligible for copyright.

name: Trademarks
period.label: Commercialization
description: A trademark is a legally registered symbol, word, or phrase that distinguishes a brand, product, or service from others.

name: Leasing contracts
period.label: Commercialization
description: A leasing contract is a legal agreement that allows one party to use an asset, such as software or hardware, for a specified period in exchange for payment.

name: Industry monopolization
period.label: Commercialization
description: Industry monopolization occurs when a single company dominates a market, limiting competition.

name: Absence of free software operating systems
period.label: Free Software Movement
description: Absence of free software operating systems refers to the period when no fully free and open-source operating system was available.

name: Open source
period.label: Free Software Movement
dependency: Software - Free Sharing of Technological Information
description: Open source refers to software with publicly available source code that anyone can inspect, modify, and distribute.

name: Sourceware
period.label: Free Software Movement
description: Sourceware was a proposed term for freely available software source code. Tiemann advocated for sourceware as a new label, while Raymond argued for the term open source.

name: Non-profit funding and support organization
period.label: Rise of Open Source
description: A non-profit funding and support organization is an entity that provides financial and logistical assistance to initiatives without seeking profit, often supporting community-driven projects.

name: Software
period.label: Mainstream Adoption
dependency: UNIX Commercialization - GNU Project - Free Software Foundation
description: Computer software was created in the early half of the 20th century. It is a set of instructions, data, or programs used to operate computers and perform specific tasks.

name: Programming
period.label: Mainstream Adoption
description: Programming is the process of writing instructions (code) that a computer can execute. It involves using programming languages like Python, Java, or C++ to create software, websites, and applications.

name: Hacking
period.label: Modern Open Source
dependency: Software - Free Sharing of Technological Information
description: Hacking is the act of gaining unauthorized access to systems, networks, or data.
